document.heading: Sexual Assault Victims" Rights Act of 2014

history.narrative: Law 20-139, the “Sexual Assault Victims' Rights Act of 2014,” was introduced in Council and assigned Bill No. 20-417. The Bill was adopted on first and second readings on April 8, 2014, and May 6, 2014, respectively. Signed by the Mayor on June 4, 2014, it was assigned Act No. 20-348 and transmitted to Congress for its review. D.C. Law 20-139 became effective on Nov. 20, 2014.

section.heading: Definitions.
section.text: For the purposes of this subchapter, the term:

para.text: “Case Review Subcommittee” means the Sexual Assault Response Team Case Review Subcommittee established by § 4-561.14.

“DC Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner Program” or “DC SANE Program” means the program that provides comprehensive care to adult victims of rape, sexual assault, and other sex crimes, operated by the OVS, in collaboration with the Network for Victim Recovery DC (or its successor entity), and the Medstar Washington Hospital Center (or its successor entity), where medical forensic exams are conducted.
“DFS” means the Department of Forensic Sciences.
“Hospital” means the MedStar Washington Hospital Center, or any medical facility where a forensic nurse examiner conducts a sexual assault forensic evaluation of the sexual assault victim.

“Independent expert consultant” or “consultant” means an independent contractor retained on a contract basis by OVS to assess and review the MPD’s response to reports of sexual assault and to ensure that all aspects of the MPD’s sexual assault investigations and training are based on current best practices, are implemented properly, and have a victim-centered approach.
“MPD” means the Metropolitan Police Department.
“OCME” means the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner.
“OVS” means the Office of Victim Services.
“SART” means the Sexual Assault Response Team established by § 4-561.12.
“Sexual assault” shall have the same meaning as provided in § 23-1907(7).
“Sexual assault victim” means an individual 18 years of age or older against whom sexual assault has been committed or is alleged to have been committed.
“Task Force” means the Sexual Assault Victim Rights Task Force established by § 4-561.15.

section.heading: Processing of sexual assault forensic examination kits and specimens.

para.text: Within 7 days after a sexual assault victim makes a report to the MPD, the MPD shall retrieve the kits and specimens and deliver:
The sexual assault forensic examination kit to the DFDFS; and
The biological specimens for toxicology testing to the OCME.
The DFS shall process all sexual assault forensic examination kits within 90 days from the date of receipt.
The OCME shall process all biological specimens within 90 days from the date of receipt.

section.heading: Payment for sexual assault forensic examination kits.
section.text: The hospital shall not bill a sexual assault victim for costs associated with the administration of a sexual assault forensic examination kit or for the kit itself.

para.text: By December 1, 2014, the OVS shall retain an independent expert consultant.
The consultant shall be selected by the Office of Police Complaints, with input from the Victim Assistance Network, subject to final approval by the OVS.
The consultant shall be retained for a period of one year, with the option for the OVS to renew that contract for a second year.

The consultant selected shall have current and recognized expertise in the areas of law enforcement, advocacy, and medical best practices, policy and procedure development, sexual assault crimes, and the investigation or prosecution of sexual assault.

section.heading: Duties.
section.text: The independent expert consultant shall have the following duties and obligations:

para.text: In consultation with the Task Force established by § 4-561.15, assess and recommend modifications to MPD policies and protocols to ensure the MPD has a detailed and victim-centered sexual assault response policy that comports with best practices and current professional standards and incorporates the requirements of the International Association of Chiefs of Police Model Policy on Sexual Assaults or other current best practices in law enforcement;
Assess training provided to MPD officers, detectives, and recruits to ensure that:
The training incorporates developments in applicable law and current best practices;
Testing is done to ensure that MPD personnel taking the training comprehend the material taught; and

Investigators conducting sexual assault investigations and personnel who supervise the review of sexual assault investigations are provided in-depth specialized training consistent with current best practices;
Review a random sample of MPD files and records related to cases arising after March 2013, including;

Sexual assault investigative files, forms, and reports, including allegations, office information cases, and other cases with sexual elements that may not have been classified as a sexual assault case; and

Feedback provided to the MPD from members of the public about the MPD’s response to sexual assault cases, including surveys, complaints, and any other feedback provided through e-mail or the MPD’s web page;

Conduct confidential interviews, when necessary, with forensic nurse examiners, sexual assault victim advocates, MPD personnel, and others with direct knowledge of how the sexual assault response process is functioning;

Within 120 days from the date of being retained by the OVS, audit all sexual assault forensic examination kits in storage to determine if all sexual assault forensic examination kits in which a sexual assault victim reported a sexual assault to law enforcement have been delivered to the DFS for processing; and
Protect the confidentiality of all MPD files and records; and
Within the reports produced by the consultant, protect the confidentiality of the underlying investigations.
The independent expert consultant shall:
Prepare, by June 1, 2015, and on a semiannual basis thereafter, a public report that contains:
A description of the work conducted by the independent expert consultant for that period;

The methodology and specific findings for each review conducted, including a general description of the policies and procedures reviewed, the observations of the consultant regarding the MPD’s implementation of those policies and procedures, the training reviewed, and a discussion of any improvements that need to be made;

A determination of whether the MPD’s implementation of reforms made after March 2013 are having a positive effect on the overall investigations of sexual assaults and whether there are any unintended negative consequences of these new policies or reforms;
A comparison of cases reported to the MPD through the DC SANE Program and MPD case numbers to ensure that all sexual assaults have been documented; and
The Chief of Police’s formal response to the report prepared pursuant to paragraph (2) of this subsection; and
Review the case review plan and process developed pursuant to § 4-561.14(d)(1), making recommendations for improvement as needed.
A draft version of the report shall be provided to the Chief of Police for review before the public issuance of the final report.
The Chief of Police shall have 30 days to review the report and prepare a formal response for purposes of a public report issued pursuant to paragraph (1) of this subsection.

The independent consultant shall, within 45 days of being retained by the OVS, develop a plan and a schedule for conducting the reviews and preparing the report described in subsection (a)(1) of this section, and shall submit this plan to the OVS for review and approval.
The plan established pursuant to paragraph (1) of this subsection shall include a timeline for submitting any recommendations to the Council or the Mayor regarding proposed legislation.
The OVS shall complete a review of the independent expert consultant’s plan developed pursuant to subsection (b) of this section within 30 days from the date of receipt.

section.heading: The MPD’s duties.
section.text: The MPD shall provide the independent expert consultant with timely, full, and direct access to the MPD’s files and records, including:

para.text: Sexual assault investigative files, forms, and reports, including allegations, office information cases, and other cases with sexual elements that may not have been classified as a sexual assault case; and

Feedback provided to the MPD from members of the public regarding the MPD’s response to sexual assault cases, including surveys, complaints, and feedback provided through e-mail or the MPD’s web page.

section.heading: Monitoring by Chief of Police.
section.text: The Chief of Police shall monitor the MPD personnel’s compliance with MPD orders and protocols related to law enforcement interaction with sexual assault victims, including the Sexual Assault Unit’s Standard Operating Procedures, when responding to sexual assault crimes.

para.text: The Chief of Police shall prepare, on an annual basis, a report on the MPD’s response to sexual assault reports. The report shall include, at a minimum:
The number of sexual assaults and attempted sexual assaults reported, identified by penal code classification;
The outcome of each reported sexual assault, identified by:
How many reports were unfounded;
How many reports were cleared, including how many cleared cases led to an arrest; and

How many reports were closed by the MPD, identified by the type of exception such as victim declines participation, suspect prosecuted in another jurisdiction, case rejected by the prosecutor, or similar explanations;
The number of:
Arrest warrants issued, by classification of crime, and arrests; and

Cases referred to prosecuting attorneys and, to the extent the information is available to the MPD, cases declined for prosecution by the prosecutor, cases declined for prosecution by the grand jury, prosecutions, and other law enforcement actions taken as a result of investigations into sexual assault reports;

The recommendations received from the Sexual Assault Response Team Case Review Subcommittee, established by § 4-561.14, and the measures the MPD has taken, if any, to address those recommendations; and
The number and type of complaints filed against MPD officers or detectives regarding their handling of sexual assault reports and any actions taken by the MPD in response to those complaints.

The report prepared pursuant to subsection (a) of this section shall be transmitted to the Mayor and the Council by December 31 of each year and be made accessible to the public; provided, that the report shall protect the privacy and confidentiality of the sexual assault victims.

section.heading: OCME reporting requirement.
section.text: In the annual report filed pursuant to § 5-1501.04(a)(5), the Director of the DFS shall include the number of sexual assault forensic examination kits received from the MPD and the number of sexual assault forensic examination kits processed by the DFS, including the time it took for each kit to be processed.

section.heading: OCME reporting requirement.
section.text: In the annual report filed pursuant to § 5-1412(d), the Chief Medical Examiner shall include the number of toxicology samples of sexual assault victims received from MPD and the number of toxicology samples of sexual assault victims processed by the OCME, including the time it took for each toxicology sample to be processed.

section.heading: Establishment of a Sexual Assault Response Team.

para.text: There is established the Sexual Assault Response Team.
The SART shall be a partnership of public and private agencies that coordinates a high-quality, multidisciplinary, victim-centered response to sexual assault cases.
Membership on the SART shall consist of the following persons:
The Director of the OVS, or his or her designee;
The SART coordinator, who shall be appointed by the Director of the OVS;
The Chief of Police, or his or her designee; provided, that the designee is a member of the Sexual Assault Unit with the rank of Captain or above;
A representative from the MPD Victim Services Branch;
The United States Attorney for the District of Columbia, or his or her designee; provided, that the designee is an attorney assigned to the Sex Offense and Domestic Violence Section;
A representative from the Victim Witness Assistance Unit of the United States Attorney’s Office for the District of Columbia;
A representative from the United States Park Police;
The Director, or his or her designee, of a private or nonprofit entity that is a member of the DC SANE Program; provided, that the designee is a forensic nurse examiner;
The Director, or his or her designee, of a community-based advocacy organization that is providing advocacy services as part of the DC SANE Program;
A representative, selected by the OVS, from a community-based organization that is providing post-assault mental health services;
A representative from the designated State Sexual Assault Coalition for the District;
The Director of DFS, or his or her designee; provided, that the designee is a forensic scientist;
The Chief Medical Examiner, or his or her designee; and

A representative from a District of Columbia-based college or university; provided, that the representative holds a position at that institution that provides direct victim services to sexual assault victims.

The SART shall hold its initial meeting within 90 days after November 20, 2014. At the initial meeting, one non-governmental member of the SART shall be elected as Chairperson by a majority of the SART members.
Following the SART’s initial meeting, the SART shall meet at least 6 times per calendar year.
The SART shall establish its own procedures and requirements with respect to the place and manner in which it will conduct its meetings.
Subchapter IV of Chapter 5 of Title 2 [§ 2-571 et seq.] does not apply to meetings of the SART.

section.heading: Duties and responsibilities of the SART.

para.text: Improve the coordination and functioning of victim services, medical forensic care, investigations, and prosecutions available to victims of sexual assault;

Conduct regular case reviews, through the Case Review Subcommittee established by § 4-561.14, of all parties involved in sexual assault responses, including a review of sexual assault reports and investigations by the MPD and cases reported to any member of the SART; and

Develop a protocol to ensure that feedback and recommendations from the Case Review Subcommittee, established by § 4-561.14, are incorporated into SART member agencies’ policies, procedures, practices, training, and decisions to re-examine investigations, when applicable.
There is established the Sexual Assault Response Team Case Review Subcommittee.
The Case Review Subcommittee shall be comprised of, at a minimum, the following SART representatives:
The SART coordinator, who shall also coordinate the Case Review Subcommittee;
The Commander of the MPD’s Sexual Assault Unit, or his or her designee; provided, that the designee is a member of the Sexual Assault Unit with the rank of Captain or above;
The Director, or his or her designee, of a private or nonprofit entity that is a member of the DC SANE Program; provided, that the designee is a forensic nurse examiner.
A representative, selected by the OVS, from a community-based organization that is providing post-assault mental health services;
The Director of DFS, or his or her designee; provided, that the designee is a forensic scientist; and
The Director, or his or her designee, of a community-based advocacy organization that is providing advocacy services as part of the DC SANE Program.
The Case Review Subcommittee shall conduct case reviews of the following types of cases:
A random sample of investigations that involve sexual assault;
Specific cases as requested by members of the SART or the Case Review Subcommittee; and
Specific cases as requested by the independent expert consultant.
The Case Review Subcommittee shall also conduct a review of complaints sexual assault victims have communicated to members of the SART.
In addition the duties set forth in subsection (c) of this section, the Case Review Subcommittee shall:

Develop a case review protocol, including a standard review form and appropriate safeguards to protect confidential or privileged information and other personal information that is protected from disclosure by federal or District law. The policy shall be reviewed on an annual basis, and revised as needed;
Develop a standard review form that examines, at a minimum, the following:
Whether each agency and service provider involved in the sexual assault response followed current best practices in each case, including:
Whether law enforcement waited at least 48 hours before conducting an interview with the sexual assault victim meant to assess and build the case; and
Whether the sexual assault victim requested information pursuant to § 23-1910 and when the sexual assault victim received that information;
Any prosecutorial actions taken;
Whether the evidence testing complied with the timing requirements of § 4-561.02; and
The use of forensic evidence in the investigation and prosecution of the case; and
Submit feedback and recommendations to the SART when the Case Review Subcommittee identifies concerns or problems during the case review process.
Subchapter IV of Chapter 5 of Title 2 [§ 2-571 et seq.] does not apply to meetings of the Case Review Subcommittee.

section.heading: Sexual Assault Victim Rights Task Force.

para.text: Beginning October 1, 2014, the OVS shall establish a Sexual Assault Victim Rights Task Force to study nationally recognized best practices and develop recommendations regarding:

The development and implementation of an effective mechanism for submitting, tracking, and investigating complaints regarding the handling of, or response to, a sexual assault report or investigation by any agency or organization involved in the response;
Whether a need exists for additional sexual assault victim advocates. If a need is identified, the Task Force shall:
Develop criteria to certify sexual assault victim advocates;
Create a plan for how the District, in conjunction with nonprofits, can provide additional sexual assault victim advocates to meet the needs identified; and
Determine the cost of funding such a plan;

Whether a need exists to expand the right to a sexual assault victim advocate beyond the hospital and law enforcement interview settings, such as meetings and conversations with prosecutors. If a need is identified, the Task Force shall:
Identify where the need exists and to what extent; and
Make recommendations on how best to fill that need, whether legislatively or otherwise;
Whether a need exists to expand the right to a sexual assault victim advocate to juvenile sexual assault victims. If a need is identified, the Task Force shall:
Identify where the need exists and to what extent; and
Make recommendations on how best to fill that need, whether legislatively or otherwise.
The Task Force shall be comprised of representatives from the following entities:
DC Sexual Assault Coalition;
DC SANE program;
DC Victim Assistance Network;
SART; and
A District of Columbia-based college or university; provided, that the representative at that institution provides direct victim services to sexual assault victims;
At least one governmental or agency-based victim services program;
At least 2 organizations for which the primary purpose of the organization is to provide services, education, or outreach to underserved populations disparately impacted by sexual assault; and
Other entities as determined by the OVS.

By September 30, 2015, the Task Force shall produce a report that includes the results of the assessments, developments, and recommendations completed pursuant to subsection (a) of this section, to be transmitted to the Council and the SART.
The Task Force shall disband after the report has been transmitted to the Council and the SART.

section.heading: No private right of action.
section.text: This subchapter shall not be construed to create a private right of action or serve as the basis for excluding otherwise admissible evidence in a criminal proceeding.

annoGroup.annotation: Section 301 of Law 20-139 provided that the Mayor, pursuant to Title I of the District of Columbia Administrative Procedure Act, approved October 21, 1968 (82 Stat. 1204; D.C. Official Code § 2-501 et seq.), may issue rules to implement the provisions of the act.
